comments.body: If you are changing the above can you add the parameters?
Maybe do this conditionally on `Split-Path -Qualifier $path`? I'm sure it's quick, but I can't think of a reason to do it if the path doesn't match...
I just noticed that `$diff_support` was renamed to `$diff_mode`. However that name was chosen on purpose. You can enable diff-support in both run-mode and check-mode, so it's not a mode in itself.

Do you have a link to this, `$diff_support` seems to me that the module is showing it supports diff, while `$diff_mode` is retrieving whether it is in diff mode or not. Really semantics in the end but if there is a common standard I will change it.

All modules that support diff output uses `$diff_support` for the _diff parameter.
There is no mechanism for a module to indicate it supports diff output.

I understand that, I liked diff_mode more as to me it indicates whether we are in diff mode or not and this is just the way I've been doing it in the modules. Does it really matter too much what this is set as?

Well, it's not a mode. You only have run-mode and check-mode. The diff option influences the output (but not the behavior of how it operates). That's why it was called _ansible_diff, and not _ansible_diff_mode (like _ansible_check_mode).

If it doesn't matter, why changing it at all :-) But yes, to me it matters to do it consistently across all modules (as what we did).

```
[dag@moria ansible.git]$ grep -rl 'diff_support' lib/ansible/modules/windows/
lib/ansible/modules/windows/win_firewall_rule.ps1
lib/ansible/modules/windows/win_timezone.ps1
lib/ansible/modules/windows/win_lineinfile.ps1
lib/ansible/modules/windows/win_environment.ps1
```
That's fair enough, makes sense when you are looking for modules that currently support it. Will add it to the agenda for the next meeting to dicuss.
